column1: #Text=Polycrystalline M3HCh samples (M = Li, Na; Ch = S, Se, Te) were synthesized via high-pressure solid-state reactions using MH and M2Ch as starting reagents.

#Text=We used as-received LiH (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), Li2S (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), NaH (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), Na2S (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%), Na2Se (Kojundo, 99%), Na2Te (Kojundo, 99%), while Li2Se and Li2Te were prepared using LiEt3BH (Sigma-Aldrich), Se (Rare Metallic Co., LTD., 99.9%) and Te (Rare Metallic Co., LTD., 99.9%).
#Text=There is a tendency that excess use of alkali metal hydride improves sample purity.
#Text=The starting materials were well-ground and pelletized, and the pellets were inserted into a boron nitride (BN) sleeve.
#Text=The two ends of the sleeve were then sealed with BN caps.
#Text=The assemble was loaded into a graphite tube heater and then enclosed in a pyrophyllite cube serving as a pressure medium.
#Text=All above procedures were handled in a N2-filled glovebox due to air and moisture sensitivity of the precursors and synthesized materials.
#Text=Finally, the assembly was pressed at 5 GPa, heated to 700 °C in 10 min, kept for 2 h, and cooled down to room temperature in 5 min before pressure was released.

#Text=All the iodine-doped samples (e.g., Na2.9H(Se0.9I0.1), Na2.9H(Te0.9I0.1), Li2.9H(S0.9I0.1)) were successfully synthesized using NaI/LiI (Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) as iodine source under the same condition with undoped one.
